That is generally the way classification training works.  I don't 
know any exceptions.  The problem is if you only train for one 
example at a time, the system doesn't need to remember what it 
previously learned in order to get the next example right.
(By the way, I'm not sure the curve is necessarily logarithmic, but 
the general point you're making sounds right)

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Chad Bohannan" <chad@b...> wrote:
> so in general, it's better to measure fitness in such a way that 
the
> fitness graph for the entire run is a single logarithmic curve, not
> repeated curves, with the hope that the curves will get smaller 
and go
> away.
> Is this a very consistant paradigm, or are there interesting 
exceptions?
> chad
> 
> 
> <-----Original Message-----> 
> >From: Kenneth Stanley
> >Sent: 8/1/2004 4:31:57 PM
> >To: neat@yahoogroups.com
> >Subject: Re: [neat] Re: 3D cross product domain
> >
> >If you are training on only a single example and every time you 
switch
> >examples it goes back to square one it sounds like the problem is
> >overspecialization. In classification tasks, you need to train on 
a
> >broad representative range of examples that every individual 
sees. 
> >Then each individual receives a score reflecting their overall
> >performance on the training set. That way, you are training for
> >generalization.
> >
> >ken
> >
> >--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Chad Bohannan" wrote:
> >> hey group,
